A 58-year-old female presents with a 6-week history of progressively worsening cognitive decline, including memory loss and difficulty concentrating, accompanied by intermittent nausea and worsening gait instability. Her family reports episodes of personality changes and episodes of confusion that have increased in frequency. She has no known history of immunosuppression or prior malignancy. Physical examination reveals mild left-sided weakness and dysarthria, with a Montreal Cognitive Assessment score of 18/30. Brain MRI demonstrates multiple enhancing lesions in the deep cerebral white matter and periventricular regions, with associated vasogenic edema. Lumbar puncture reveals elevated opening pressure and cerebrospinal fluid positive for clonal B-cells by flow cytometry. Whole-body imaging and bone marrow biopsy do not reveal lymphoma outside the CNS. A stereotactic biopsy of one lesion confirms diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the central nervous system, prompting initiation of high-dose methotrexate-based chemotherapy.
